headline: Name That Train
summary: In honor of National Train Day, see if you can match up these Amtrak services with their names, many of which hold clues that relate to the geographic areas.

headline: Euromoney 2012 Rankings
summary: Who's up? Who's down? See the results of Euromoney's 2012 FX poll here.

headline: Hong Kong Regulator Defends IPO Crackdown
summary: The chances a banker would face jail time under Hong Kong's proposed IPO rules are slim, the head of the securities regulator said, defending the rules in the face of banker complaints.

headline: FDA Panel Backs HIV Drug for Preventive Use
summary: An FDA advisory panel voted to back the use of an HIV drug made by Gilead Sciences to help prevent certain healthy but at-risk people from contracting the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of May 11, 2012

headline: Chaoda's Auditor Resigns
summary: Chaoda Modern Agriculture, whose Hong Kong-listed shares have been suspended from trading since September, said that auditor BDO has resigned because it was unable to complete its audit of the company's annual results.

headline: Chesapeake Deals Carry $1.4 Billion Liability
summary: Chesapeake Energy has saddled itself with about $1.4 billion of previously unreported liabilities over the next decade through off-balance-sheet financial deals.

headline: No More Three-Martini Lunches, But Metro-North Bar Cars Remain
summary: Uncorking the City: There aren't many vestiges left of 1970s New York, but among them none may be more beloved than the bar cars on Metro-North's New Haven line.

headline: Chromosome Talk For Lunching Set
summary: There may be no better way to spend a balmy spring afternoon than lunching with friends under a canopy spread upon a grassy lawn. Nothing better, that is, unless the refreshments were preceded by a lecture about chromosomes and DNA.

headline: Internet Gambling Bill Moves Forward in N.J.
summary: An Internet gambling bill being considered by New Jersey lawmakers could allow Atlantic City's casinos to take bets from people in other states or countries, although key details remain to be worked out.

headline: In Canada, Alternate Currency Keeps Traction With Fans
summary: An iconic retailer whose coupons have gained currency outside the store's doors is starting to phase out the program in a shift toward a plastic loyalty-card system.

headline: China Inflation Eases In April; Provides Room For Easing
summary: China's consumer inflation eased in April, which could give more room for monetary easing in the world's second largest economy to support growth.

headline: The Legacy of Man Ray
summary: Man Ray, a pioneering photographer and early champion of Surrealism, bequeathed the contents of his studio to his wife, Juliet, over 30 years ago. Today, her relatives still keep 4,500 of his works in their car-repair shop in Long Island, N.Y. Man Ray's nephew, Roger Browner, recently gave the Journal a tour.

headline: Where the Food Is Free
summary: They say there's no such thing as a free lunch, but a staple at Sikh temples across the world is the langar, a kitchen where food is offered without charge. The Sikh Cultural Society in Richmond Hill, Queens feeds 500 people on a typical day and more than 1,000 on Sundays.

headline: Credit Suisse, Goldman Sachs Cut A$ Forecasts
summary: Credit Suisse and Goldman Sachs on Friday sharply lowered their outlook for the Australian dollar blaming slower economic data and weakening demand for Australian debt.

headline: First Debate Marks Race to Lead Egypt
summary: The two front-runners in Egypt's presidential contest squared off in the country's first presidential debate, as candidates entered the homestretch of a campaign set to end six decades of military-backed dictatorship.

headline: Warren Listed as White in School Records
summary: Democratic Senate hopeful Elizabeth Warren listed herself as white in personnel records at the University of Texas and declined to apply to Rutgers School of Law through a minority program, records show.

headline: Espada Case Jurors Noting Progress
summary: On their ninth day of deliberations, the federal jury weighing corruption and embezzlement charges against former state Sen. Pedro Espada Jr. and his son sent the judge a curious note.

headline: In Haiti, Agitating for New Army
summary: A brewing rebellion from ex-members of Haiti's disbanded army is adding uncertainty to the poor country one year after President Michel Martelly began his term with a pledge of renewal in the wake of a devastating 2010 earthquake.

headline: Deadly Syria Blasts Stoke New Fears
summary: Twin car bombs in the Syrian capital killed 55 people and injured nearly 400 more in a gruesome setback to a U.N.-brokered peace plan.

headline: Winners of Obama Dinner Raffle Named
summary: A New Jersey science teacher and a Florida utility-company worker won an Obama campaign raffle entitling them to mingle with A-list celebrities at actor George Clooney's home in Los Angeles.

headline: Strassel: Trolling for Dirt on the President's List
summary: First a Romney supporter was named on an Obama campaign website. That was followed by the slimy trolling into a citizen's private life.

headline: Carpenter and Knepper: Do Barbers Really Need a License?
summary: Cosmetologists in many states face substantially heavier training requirements than do emergency medical technicians.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Nadal Leaves Madrid Feeling Blue
summary: After suffering a third-round upset at the Madrid Open on Thursday, Rafael Nadal said the tournament's surface needed to change or he would be forced to skip the event in the future.

headline: U.N. Fund Scrutinized for Corruption
summary: A joint international-Afghan anticorruption watchdog plans to flag a "pattern of bad behavior" regarding potential mismanagement at the U.N.-administered trust fund that bankrolls Afghanistan's fledgling police force.

headline: Mideast Nuclear Meeting in Doubt
summary: Plans for a U.N.-backed conference aimed at ridding the Mideast of nuclear weapons are unraveling because of upheaval in the region and diplomatic sparring over suspected nuclear-weapons programs in Iran and Israel.

headline: President Plants Feet on Rapidly Shifting Terrain
summary: How Obama's shift in his stance on gay marriage is perceived will go some way toward determining where the country ends up on what remains a contentious issue.

headline: Is GNC Overstimulated?
summary: Shares in GNC Holdings have been running flat out. But a controversy surrounding an ingredient in some top-selling products could cause the vitamin retailer to lose some pep.

headline: Henry Miller: ObamaCare's Killer Device Tax
summary: The U.S. leads the world in medical technology. A punitive new excise levy jeopardizes jobs and innovation.

headline: Private Properties
summary: Merv Griffin's former estate is reduced 34%; Sheik Tarek Al Fassi sells in Miami Beach; a Maryland estate of Phillips Seafood's Stephen and Maxine Phillips lists for $32 million.

headline: Tebow Renames His Dog to Fit With New York
summary: Plus, Wayne Hunter says he's been told he's a starter for the Jets next season.

headline: An Extreme Kayaker's Modern Habitat
summary: Perched on a bluff above the Columbia River Gorge, the 3,500-square-foot contemporary has a view of the changing river waters in an area that's known as a mecca for outdoor sports.

headline: Riding With the Cisco Skid
summary: There is no mistaking Cisco Systems for a tech dynamo anymore.

headline: Junk Is Ferried by Pacific Current
summary: A big, sluggish Pacific current that can take three years or more to complete its 6,800-mile-long circuit carries a burden of floating junk—from freight washed overboard to the wreckage swept to sea in the aftermath of the earthquake that struck Japan last year.

headline: Living in 'Sunny' San Francisco
summary: This 1,947-square-foot Victorian home with three bedrooms and three bathrooms in San Francisco's sunnier Noe Valley neighborhood is asking $1.7 million.

headline: French Unions Expect Big Layoffs
summary: During the recent presidential campaign, when unemployment was a fraught political issue, companies avoided announcing job cuts. But now that it's over, unions say many large French companies are preparing to announce large layoffs.

headline: Chesapeake Flies in Front of Fractional-Jet Set
summary: Chesapeake Energy, which came under fire in a shareholder lawsuit over the cost of personal travel aboard company jets by executives, is by far the largest single owner of fractional aircraft shares in the U.S.

headline: Trade Gap Widens as Imports Show Rise
summary: The U.S. trade deficit widened in March but other data reflected two conditions that could spur the economic recovery: strong American exports and falling oil prices.

headline: SEC Probes Inland REIT
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating an $11 billion real-estate company for potential violations of federal securities laws, casting a shadow over the business of real estate investment trusts that aren't traded on exchanges.

headline: Closing Bell Rings for Exchange's Name
summary: The name of the American Stock Exchange, once among the most prominent stock markets in the world, is going the way of ticker tape.

headline: Sinn Fein Urges Rejection of EU Treaty
summary: Gerry Adams, head of Ireland's Sinn Fein party, is calling on Irish voters to join their counterparts in Greece, Spain and other parts of Europe in rejecting austerity policies that have failed to resolve the bloc's debt crisis.

headline: Euro's Resilience Has Its Limits
summary: The convulsions rocking the Continent this week have convinced some analysts and investors that the euro's recent slippage presages a bigger fall.

headline: 'Wish' Granted: A Jewel, About Kids
summary: Plus, Johnny Depp, Tim Burton and a big budget get lost in "Dark Shadows"; "Where Do We Go Now?" is brave and startlingly funny, writes Joe Morgenstern.

headline: Peru's Defense, Interior Ministers Resign
summary: Peru's defense and interior ministers resigned on Thursday, amid growing pressure over their handling of an operation to capture the remnants of the Shining Path rebel group, the government said.

headline: Art: The Gray-Eyed Girl
summary: A haunting portrait of a child is among 15 masterpieces on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in "Bellini, Titian, and Lotto: North Italian Paintings from the Accademia Carrara, Bergamo."

headline: Howard Stern Readies for 'America's Got Talent'
summary: Plus, new album from the Best Coast, "The Only Place"; China Miéville's "Railsea."

headline: FDA Panel Backs New Obesity Drug
summary: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee recommended the agency approve an Arena Pharmaceuticals drug to treat obesity, the second time this year advisers have backed a fat-fighting medication.

headline: New Wave of Departures at Dewey
summary: In one of the largest one-day defections from beleaguered New York law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, at least 27 partners, including two firm leaders headed for the exits on Wednesday.

headline: Deutsche Bank to Pay $202 Million to Settle Suit
summary: The Justice Department alleged that the bank's MortgageIT unit lied to maintain access to federal housing-loan financing.

headline: Germany: Do as We Say, Not as We Do
summary: Germany's solution to the euro-zone crisis is for other countries to become more like Germany. Or at least more like the way Germany sees itself. For some economists, it's not so much that the advice is wrong, it's the timing that's bad.

headline: Science Scores Draw Concern
summary: U.S. eighth-graders made modest gains on the latest national science exam, but more than two-thirds still lacked a solid grasp of facts.

headline: Merv Griffin Estate Near Palm Springs Sees a Price Cut
summary: Merv Griffin's former estate near Palm Springs is reduced 34%; Sheik Tarek Al Fassi sells in Miami Beach; a Maryland estate of Phillips Seafood's Steve and Maxine Phillips lists for $32 million.

headline: P&G Moves Unit to Asia
summary: Procter & Gamble is moving its global beauty, skin, cosmetics and personal-care unit to Singapore from Cincinnati.

headline: Funds Assets Increase
summary: Assets in money-market funds gained $1.19 billion in the week ended Wednesday as modest inflows to institutional funds more than offset declines from retail funds.

headline: The Smart Way to Follow 'Dumb Money'
summary: "Go with the flow" may be great advice in some areas of life, but not when it comes to investing.

headline: Ex-Tabloid Editor: 'No Quid Pro Quo' With Government
summary: The onetime News of the World editor who became a top aide to the U.K.'s Cameron told an inquiry there was no inappropriate relationship between his former employers.

headline: Still Green, but Not a Pleasant Land?
summary: Theodore Dalrymple's April 20 op-ed "The Ugly Brutishness of Modern Britain" didn't sit well with some of your readers, based on the May 1 letters in response. Those readers present, however, opinions that contradict actual facts.

headline: Getting Parole From 'Customer Service' Voice-Mail Jail
summary: When does a conservative corporatist become a consumer advocate? When his own ox is gored. Welcome to Stephen Moore and his compelling piece about the automated answering services of the airlines and many other businesses that make customers wait and wait and listen to ads ("'Press 9 for More Options'" (op-ed, May 4).

headline: Blowing in the Wind, at a Very High Cost to Consumers
summary: Your May 5 editorial "Gouged by the Wind" is a powerful blow for sanity. If users of electric energy in Minnesota are paying only a whopping $0.1076 per kilowatt-hour, then we in New Jersey should wish for similar good fortune.

headline: A Case for German Pinot Noir
summary: In Germany, a new wave of winemakers is harnessing the twin powers of technology and climate change to produce noteworthy Pinot Noir.

headline: Buffett Bats for Coty's Avon Offer
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway emerged as a major backer of Coty's bid for struggling beauty company Avon, but Berkshire's support had the unexpected effect of signaling the deal might never come together.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In Friday's photos, two boxers duke it out in China, a Beatle draws a crowd in Mexico, children ride a merry-go-round in Pakistan, and more.

headline: Express Scripts Earnings Down 18%
summary: Espress Scripts said its earnings fell 18% as acquisition-related expenses weighed on the pharmacy-benefit manager's bottom-line.

headline: FDA Warns of MS Treatment
summary: The Food and Drug Administration cautioned that a controversial treatment for multiple sclerosis has been tied to serious complications, including stroke and death.

headline: WageWorks, Audience Rise in Debuts
summary: Two IPOs made first-day gains, with shares of employee benefit administrator WageWorks and mobile audio technology firm Audience closing up from their offering prices.

headline: Crop Outlook Slams Corn
summary: Prices for the crop fell 2.5% after the U.S. government raised its forecast for near-term supplies of the grain and projected a record harvest this autumn.

headline: Earnings in Private Equity  Aren't a Simple Matter
summary: A question most companies can easily answer comes with complications when posed to publicly traded private-equity firms: What count as earnings?

headline: Photos of the Day: May 10
summary: In today's pictures, a farmer picks strawberries in Germany, storks gather in India, a teen dies in a golf cart accident in Tennessee, and more.

headline: T-Mobile Customer Losses Mount
summary: T-Mobile said it lost more than a half million of the most lucrative customers in the first quarter, casting doubt on whether the company can regain momentum after regulators blocked its sale to AT&T.

headline: It's Good to Have a King
summary: Why did hereditary rulers independently arise in so many cultures? Perhaps because lineage is a sensible basis for selecting leaders. Felipe Fernández-Armesto reviews.

headline: Robert Hahn and Peter Passell: How Much to Escape From Heathrow?
summary: Let travelers with more money than time buy their way out of long passport-control lines.

headline: Karl Rove: Obama's Public-Equity Record
summary: The auto bailout makes Bain Capital look like an amateur on job losses and outsourcing.

headline: Gold Ends Slightly Higher
summary: Gold futures eked out a slight gain, rising for the first time this week as relative calm in Europe drew buyers back to the precious metal after a three-day selloff.
